description: The Pioneer Building appears to the left followed by Hotel Seattle. The Olympic Block and Merchant's Cafe appear to the right.

description: View south from 2nd Ave. and Pine St.

title: The Oasis Restaurant souvenir photograph, June 8, 1948Page 1
description: The Oasis was a dinner club popular in the 1940s that operated on Aurora Avenue.

description: Transcribed from photograph: "Views. From Denny Hill. 1882. Looking East. 1. Otto Ranke house. 2. Harry Bigelow house."

description: Suzzallo Library opened on the University of Washington Campus in 1926. title: View NE from 3rd Ave. and Marion St., ca. 1941Front
description: The Northern Life Tower can be seen at the left of the photograph with the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Co. Building in front of it. The Olympic Hotel, YWCA and Central Library can be  seen in the center of the photograph. Lake Union appears in the distance on the right.
subjects: Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company Building (Seattle, Wash.)

title: West Seattle Ferry and Seattle Yacht Club anchorage, ca. 1910Front
description: The West Seattle Ferry dock appears in the center of the photograph, followed by moored yachts and the Seattle Terminal and Railway Elevator Company at the far right.
subjects: Seattle Terminal and Railway Elevator Company

title: University of Washington trail through snow, January 1916Front
Snow at 2nd Ave. and Marion St., 1916Front
description: View north on 2nd Ave. from Marion St. The Rialto Building appears on the left. Signs for the Circuit Theater and Empress Building appear on the right.

title: Yukon Club souvenir photograph, ca. 1948Page 1
Town Ranch Restaurant souvenir photograph, March 21, 1945Page 1
description: The Town Ranch opened in 1942. It featured dinner and dancing along with traveling vaudeville acts.

title: Storytime at Collins Playfield, ca. 1910
description: The Collins Playfield was developed in 1907 and located between S. Washington St, S. Main St., 14th Ave. S. and 16th Ave. S. The playfield served as a library deposit station where children could pick up library books starting in 1909. The photograph caption identifies the librarian reading the stories as Ms. Andrews.
intersection: 16th Ave. S. and S. Washington St.

title: Seattle Central Library Reference Department, ca. 1909
description: The Reference Department was located in the Carnegie Central Library, designed by P.J. Weber and opened in 1906.

title: Model airplane contest, August 1914
description: According to the library's 1914 annual report: "In August the library conducted an aeroplane contest managed by Miss Hunter, children's librarian of the University branch. The original plan was for a contest among the boys of the University District only, but the interest was so widespread that it was finally opened to all the boys in the city. With the help of Mr. Howard Stine, playground director of the Park Department, and the playground instructors, the field arrangements were made and two contests were held a week apart. Prizes were donated by various interested people of the city and much newspaper publicity was secured. One of the large department stores displayed the prices in its window together with some of the models entered. , and moving pictures of the meet were shown at a local theater the following week. The books on model aeroplanes are in constant circulation and there is great interest in the possibility of another contest in 1915. Many boys who formerly regarded the library as a place to prepare lessons, now look upon it as a source of information on subjects in which they are keenly interested." An August 27, 1914 Seattle Star article lists the location of the meet at the Optimo Playfield at 29th Ave. and E. Cherry St. An August 20, 1914 article in the Seattle Times which announced the rules for the competition refers to the field as Optimo Grounds.

title: Seattle Public Library from 4th Ave. and Madison St., ca. 1940
description: The Carnegie Central Library, designed by P.J. Weber, opened in 1906. Hotel Hungerford can be seen on the far left side of the photograph.

title: Georgetown Library Branch, 1912
description: Located in the Georgetown City Hall building, the library branch opened in November 1912.

title: Seattle Public Library booth at Child Welfare Exhibit, May 25-31, 1914
description: According to the 1914 annual report: "The Library's share in the Child Welfare Exhibit, held at the Armory the last week in May, consisted of space twelve by thirty feet in which a miniature children's room was installed, with low tables, chairs, pictures, and flowering plants. About 600 books purchased for the Yesler Branch, which opened in September, were shelved in the library enclosure and these were circulated to children holding library cards. At one end of the space were seven screens telling of library activities by means of photographs and posters. Special shelves were reserved for books recommended for a child's own library, a collection of undesirable books for children, and a list of books for mothers concerning care of children. A list of books for a child's own library was distributed and a pamphlet called "Library babies are better babies" was given out. Attendants were always in charge to explain the work of the library to visitors, and the grown people were so interested that at times the children were crowded out." The Armory Building that housed the exhibit stood from 1909 to 1968 in the location now occupied by Victor Steinbrueck Park.

title: Children reading at wading pool, ca. 1915
description: Location of the photograph is unclear. The 1915 Report of the Board of Park Commissioners lists three playground locations containing wading pools: Hiawatha Playfield (located at California Ave. SW and SW Lander St.), Lincoln Playfield (now Bobby Morris Playfield and Cal Anderson Park at E. Pine St. and 11th Ave.), and Queen Anne Playfield (located at 1st Ave. W. and W. Blaine St.). Woodland Park also had a wading pool during this time period.

title: Seattle Central Library Fine Arts and Technology Department, ca. 1914
description: The Fine Arts and Technology Department was located in the Carnegie Central Library, designed by P.J. Weber and opened in 1906. The room's attendant, Mr. Thompson, is seated at the desk. The 1914 City Directory lists Claude S. Thompson as the technology librarian at the Central Library.
subjects: Seattle Public Library. Fine Arts and Technology Department

title: Children's books in cabinet, ca. 1910
description: This set is likely part of what the library called it's "school duplicate collection" which supplied books directly to the classroom. According to the library's 1908 annual report, "Sets of twenty volumes are sent to school rooms in grades four to eight inclusive. Reference books in limited numbers are also placed in the principals' offices and drawn from there by teachers. These reference collections contain from 50 to 90 volumes each. In the first, second, and third grades, picture books and pleasure readers are furnished in sets of twenty-four volumes each for use in the school rooms under the direct supervision of the teachers. During the past year 66 public parochial, and Sunday schools have been supplied with books."

title: Group of children at Collins Playfield Deposit Station, ca. 1912
description: The Collins Playfield was developed in 1907 and located between S. Washington St, S. Main St., 14th Ave. S. and 16th Ave. S. The playfield served as a library deposit station where children could pick up library books starting in 1909. The fieldhouse shown here was constructed in 1912.
intersection: 16th Ave. S. and S. Washington St.

title: Ballard Library Branch, 1910
description: The Ballard library was constructed in 1904 prior to the town's 1907 annexation to Seattle. When the town was annexed, it became part of the Seattle Public Library system. The library moved to a new location on 24th Ave. NW in 1963.

title: Seattle Central Library Bindery, February 1921
description: The Bindery was located in the Carnegie Central Library, designed by P.J. Weber and opened in 1906. The calendar posted on wall shows the year is 1921.

title: Queen Anne Library Branch interior, ca. 1914
description: The Queen Anne Library opened on January 1, 1914.
subjects: Seattle Public Library. Queen Anne Library

title: Seattle Central Library Reference Department, ca. 1909
description: The Reference Department was located in the Carnegie Central Library, designed by P.J. Weber and opened in 1906.

title: Library story hour in an unidentified school, ca. 1915
description: As part of the their outreach efforts, the Library's children's department staff visited local schools for story hours. The library also provided classrooms with "school duplicate collections," a selection of 20 books which could be checked out to students (see spl_shp_222182_056), and reference materials for staff. The location of the classroom shown here is unknown.

title: Seattle Central Library Children's Room, ca. 1909
description: The Children's Room was located in the Carnegie Central Library, designed by P.J. Weber and opened in 1906.

title: Library Deposit Station No. 1, Weeds Pharmacy, 1912
description: The 1912 City Directory lists a Melvin A. Weed, druggist, at 2601 Jackson St.

title: Yesler Library Branch, ca. 1914
description: The Yesler Library, named for Seattle pioneer Henry Yesler, opened in 1914. In 1975, the name of the library was changed to Douglass-Truth in honor of Frederick Douglass and Sojourner Truth.

title: Firehouse Deposit Station, ca. 1912
description: Exact location of firehouse unknown.
